message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The subepidermal blisters with an eosinophil-rich infiltrate point to dermatitis herpetiformis or bullous pemphigoid. However, the location of blisters on the flexor surfaces of the upper extremities and trunk suggests bullous pemphigoid. The linear band of IgG in the epidermal basement membrane is a characteristic finding in bullous pemphigoid.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of tense blisters on the flexor surfaces of the upper extremities and trunk, along with histologic findings of a linear band of IgG in the epidermal basement membrane, suggest pemphigus vulgaris. Autoantibodies to desmoglein 3 are the cause of pemphigus vulgaris. Granular deposits of IgA in the dermal papilla are characteristic of dermatitis herpetiformis, and linear band of IgA in the basement membrane suggest linear IgA dermatosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of subepidermal blisters with an eosinophil-rich infiltrate suggests dermatitis herpetiformis, which is caused by a linear band of IgA in the epidermal basement membrane.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of large tense blisters on the flexor surfaces of the upper extremities and trunk with histologic findings of subepidermal blisters with an eosinophil-rich infiltrate is consistent with bullous pemphigoid, which is characterized by a linear band of IgG in the epidermal basement membrane. Autoantibodies to desmoglein 3 are associated with pemphigus vulgaris, granular deposits of IgA in the dermal papilla are associated with dermatitis herpetiformis, and a linear band of IgA in the basement membrane is associated with linear IgA bullous dermatosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of large tense blisters on the flexor surfaces of the upper extremities and trunk, along with the histologic findings of a linear band of IgG in the epidermal basement membrane, is consistent with the diagnosis of bullous pemphigoid.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The subepidermal blisters with an eosinophil-rich infiltrate suggest dermatitis herpetiformis, which is caused by a linear band of IgA in the epidermal basement membrane. The other options are associated with different conditions: desmoglein 3 is associated with pemphigus vulgaris, granular deposits of IgA are associated with IgA dermatosis (formerly known as dermatitis herpetiformis), and IgA in the basement membrane is associated with linear IgA bullous dermatosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of large tense blisters on flexor surfaces and trunk with eosinophil-rich infiltrate is characteristic of bullous pemphigoid, which is caused by a linear band of immunoglobulin G (IgG) in the epidermal basement membrane. The other options are associated with other autoimmune blistering disorders.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of subepidermal blisters with an eosinophil-rich infiltrate suggests dermatitis herpetiformis, which is associated with linear IgA deposits in the basement membrane. None of the other options are consistent with this type of presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of eosinophil-rich infiltrate and subepidermal blisters suggests dermatitis herpetiformis, which is caused by IgA deposits in the basement membrane. None of the other options match the histologic findings or the clinical presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of subepidermal blisters and eosinophil-rich infiltrate suggests bullous pemphigoid, which is characterized by a linear band of IgG in the epidermal basement membrane. All other options correspond to different types of autoimmune blistering diseases.
